div.head: A GARTER FOR LORD CROMER
div.p: What is to be Lord Cromer's reward ? On every side the desire is expressed, says the Liberal organ, "The Tribune," that the services of the great Pro-consul shall be recognized by the conferment of some signal honour to mark the nation's gratitude upon the completion of the memorable epoch in the history of the Empire.

What form the reward shall take is already, the subjet of keep discussion, but such a wealth of honours has been heaped upon Lord Cromer during his diplomatic career that the choice of elevation has become somewhat circumscribed He is a member of tho Privy Council. He has received the Grand Cross Of the Oders of the Bath and the St. Michael and St. George. He is a Knight Commander of the Star of Indian, a Companion of the Order of the Indian Empire, and one of the fifteen British members of the Order of Merit. Finally, during his administration he has been successively created baron (1892), viscount (1898). and earl (1901).

Among the many suggestions which are being thrown out, the moat general appear to be that Lord Cromer shall be given a further step in the peerage or receive a money grant. As far as can be ascertained there is no precedent whatever for the grant of a sum ol money to a retiring diplomat. It has often been done in the case of a military commander fresh from a successful campaign, and the cases of Lord Kitchener and Lord Roberts are still fresh in the public mind.

But the great civilian is not similarly favoured, and the case of Lord Dufferin is decisive as to the practice on such occasions. Lord Dufferin had rendered unexampled services to this country during his occupancy of the offices of Viceroy of India, Governor-General of Canada, and Ambassador at St Petersburg, Constantinople, Rome, and Paris, but though notoriously a poor man, he received no financial recognition beyond the customary pension on his retirement from the Diplomatic Service in 1896 Not only slid he not receive a giant on leaving the Paris Embassy, but he was not specially honoured in any way.

Precedent also is against Lord Cromer in the circumstances receiving a marquisate. The Earl of Hopetoun was certainly created Marquess of Linlithgow on resigning tha Governor-Generalship of Australia in 1902, but this was merely an enhanced dignity for an old peerage. The same applies to the marquisate conferred upon Lord Ripor upon the settlement of the Alabama claims in 1871, and in a less degree to the title bestowed upon Lord Dufferiu in 1888 at the close of his Viceroyalty. In neither case was the marquisate conferred at the close of a career, and neither recipient began public life as a commoner, as Lord Cromer did. It is further pointed out that even a Prime Minister of this country sitting in the Commons has no claim upon a higher title than that of EarL Walpole, the elder Pitt, and Disraeli received earldoms, and it is an open secret that Mr. Gladstone refused one.

There is, however, an honour far transcending that of a step in the peerage which may fittingly and with sufficient precedent be conferred upon Lord Cromer In well-informed quarters the belief is entertained that be will be offered the Garter. By tradition the Garter is the gift of the King, and its conferment upon Lord Cromer would have an international significance, seeing that it is the order associated with sovereignty. The precedent is a very striking one— that of Lord Stratford de Redcliffe, "the Great Elchi," who received the Garter in 1869 in recognition of his services as Ambassador at Constantinople. Stratford Canning's Garter was especially noteworthy because it was one of the extremely rare instances of that favour being bestowed upon a peer below the rank of an Earl.

At the present moment the Order of the Garter has its full complement of twenty-four knights, the most recent vacancy having been filled by Earl Carrington, Lord Stratford had to wait for a vacancy before receiving the Garter, but there is a precedent for temporarily raising the number of knights in exceptional circumstances. When Disraeli and Lord Salisbury returned from Berlin in 1878, after negotiating the famous treaty, both statesmen were given the Garter, although there was only one vacancy.
If Lord Cromer becomes a Knight of the Garter on his return from Egypt a deserved honour will have been conferred without creating the possibility of a dangerous precedent.

div.head: Sandstorm at Suez
div.p: Under date of yesterday our Suez Correspondent writes:—Yesterday owing to the strong northerly wind and sand storm, all steamers had to be moored in the Canal till the afternoon when a large number of steamers came out of the Canal. The same thing was done in the Suez roads, and several steamers were waiting to enter. Towards the evening a procession of no less than 15 steamers entered the Canal.

div.head: Cyprus as a Health Resort
div.p: The Asia Minor S.S. Co. of Alexandria are commencing their regular summer sailings to Cyprus porta about June 1st. The company's passenger steamers run direct from Alexandria to Limassol, thence to Famagusta and Larnaca, returning to Alexandria via Port Said. The round trip occupying some 67 days in a pleasant one, and we can recommend it to those who are fond of a sea voyage. The climate of the Cyprus high lands is particularly fine and the island, being within easy reach of Egypt, is becoming yearly a more favourite summer resort.

div.head: Three Fires in Alexandria
div.p: Yesterday the fire brigade were called out three times First at 10.10 a.m. to an outbreak at the offices of the Tramway Co. in Boulevard de Ramleh, where a large cupboard was practically destroyed; it was extingnished by chemical apparatus : at 7.47 last evening to the Midan where one room and staircase were damaged, and at 10.20 to an oil and colour shop in the Attarin quarter, where the door had to he burst open to get at the fire, which was quickly extinguished by means of one hydrant. This brings the total number of fires up to 70 this year.

div.head: Donkey Polo in Sennar
div.p: There is a delightful touch of humour contained in that portion of Lord Cromer's Report which deals with the Sudan. In summarising Major Wilson's report on the province of Sennar, Lord Cromer remarks that the "following observation is characteristic of British administration. Major Wilson writes : 'Advantage was taken of the pressence of numerous head sheikhs at the cotton show to initiate them into the game of polo on donkeys. Matches were played between teams of sheikhs, who took to the game in an extraordinary manner. " The "Spectator" in commenting on this passage remarks : "It seems to us that Major Wilson by his bold experiment with the Sennar sheikhs may have unconsciously produced world-wide results. Polo on donkeys would be an admirable new sport for elderly men of action for whom real polo has become too dangerous. We also recommend donkey polo to enterprising hostesses in country houses anxious to find amusement for their guests. Most mining villages, as well as most seaside resorts, ought easily to be able to produce eight donkeys to make a beginning, while country houses in Kent and Essex would have the whole of the coster donkeys of the East End to draw upon. We wonder whether the donkeys soon get keen on the game like ponies, and learn to follow the ball. Also, do their ears get in the way ?"

div.head: TROUBLES IN CAIRO.
div.p: SERIOUS DISTURBANCES.
MILITARY DEMONSTRATION

A serious state of affairs prevails in Cairo and there is a very uneasy feeling prevalent that troubles of a grave nature may break out. So seriously indeed is the situation regarded by the officials that Mr Machell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, who had left on a journey to Mariout, has had to be recalled to Cairo. The strike of the cabmen, as we announced on Friday, is over and on Saturday the cabs were plying as usual. But as soon as this strike had been settled the carters began to rise up and a grave series of outrages took place on Saturday, which has alarmed the inhabitants of the Capital, for the movement is not considered to be solely provoked by economical reasons. At 11 am. a large mob, consisting of many hundreds of natives, assembled suddenly at the khalig near Darb el Gamamy and at once began to savagely attack the trams. The mob broke the windows, maltreated the employes of the Tramway company and the passengers: all traffic was stopped and the street blocked. At the same time another huge mob gathered together in the Gouvernoat square Mansfield Pasha harangued them in Arabic and the mounted police cleared the square. Twenty employes of the Cairo Tramway Company have been injured and forty-three tram cars have been damaged. It is considered that these outrages have been inspired by some well-known persons who want to encourage disorder for their own purposes.

The serious outrages in the trams have no perceptible connection with either the strike ol the cabmen or the carters. There were other outbursts of the mob and at Abou el Ala bridge a crowd assembled. The manifests, who had a threatening attitude, were prevented from doing any harm and the police made some arrests. All traffic on the tram lines at Boulac, Old Cairo, and the Khalig was suspended at 6 p.m. and on the other lines at between 9 and 10 p.m. Egyptian troops were stationed at the poliee posts.
POPULAR ALARM.

The Cairo newspapers express the alarm felt generally at these disorders. "Les Pyramides" remarks "what is particularly disquieting in this one is that the outcry is not made against the employers, as is usually the case in strike troubles, but against the Government and its agents. Some people are asking themselves whether these demands, whose object is to alarm public opinion and which, moreover, are not due to trade interests, do not conceal political issues are fomented by some people whose interest it is to disturb the water in order to fish the better."

The "Journal du Caire" in its issue of Saturday also expresses the popular alarm at these sudden and simultaneous outbreaks ot disorder after the cessation of the cab Strike. It remarks : 'We had good reason to declare in ourlast issue that there were evilly disposed persons who wished to fish in troubled water. This cannot any longer admit of the slightest doubt in view of the fresh outbreak of disorder this morning. The cabs are plying again and yet the trams are attacked ! Why is this ? What can he the motive for it! Who are the people who are directing it. We hold that we have the right to put these questions and it is the duty of the police to answer. This stupid but suggestive agitation has continued too long. These recent events clearly show that at the present time there is a large number of people in Cairo without any occupation, whose pleasure it is to utilise their leisure in the refined amusement of maltreating the passengers and the staff of the tramways. In such a case the poliee in every country in the world sweeps them away and clears the town of this disagreeable class. When are we to have a clearance at Cairo ?'

It is to be noted as a coincidence of some significance that both these newspapers, from which we have quoted, and which appear at the same time,make use of the same expression "pecher en eau trouble."
LATEST NEWS.

Our Cairo correspondent telephoning to-day at 1 p.m. states that there has been no renewal of the disorders to-day. Last night the whole force of the Cairo City Police were on duty and in readiness for any emergency. The Ministry of the Interior had taken special measures to ensure the safety of the Cairo Gouvernorat from attack and it was guarded by soldiers. Throughout yesterday there was a vague presentiment of coming troubles and a renewal of the disturbances but no incidents of a serious character are reported.
The carters of Cairo, who are among the roughest elements of the populace, remain quiet.
The troops of the Anny of Occupation were called out last night and paraded round the Boulac quarter, where the troubles appeared to be the gravest.
The demonstration has had, it is hoped, a good effect. If, however, the disorders continue the most severe measures will be token to ensure quiet.

Extraordinarily disquieting rumours were afloat at Alexandria this morning as to the state of affairs in the Capital and it was confidently announced that the troops of the Army of Occupation had had to be called out. The news exerted a very bad effect in the Bourse and considerable nervousness was the result.

div.head: LORD CROMERS RESIGNATION
div.p: MEETING AT ALEXANDRIA.

The special committee of the Alexandria Municipal Commission couvened a general meeting at the Municipal Palace at 11 o'clock yesterday morning in order to discuss the question of a memorial to Lord Cromer. The attendance was very representative, with the noticeable exception that outside the representatives of the Press there was not a single Moslem present. The discussion was long and desultory and the meeting did not break up until 1.30 p m. Some confusion has been caused owing to the fact that after the special committee of the Municipality had sent a letter to Lord Cromer and had received a reply from his lordship in favour of a tuberculous institution, a letter was received from the President of the Council of Ministers asking Alexandria to join with Cairo. The Cairo committee had nominated some Alexandria to serve on a general committee but had neglected to ask the Alexandria Municipality to select some of its members for this purpose. Mr. Salvago strongly protested in the name of the Municipality at this treatment. The Municipality was the most important representative institution in Egypt and was representative of Alexandria, and it was a grave want of taste not to ask it officially to select some of its members to serve on the committee and to ignore the fact that the Municipality had taken the initiative in the matter.

It was decided that Schiess Pasha, Mr. Salvago and Pados Bey should go to Cairo in order to discuss the question with the committee there and put forward Alexandria's views. It was also agreed that Alexandria should take part in the manifestation at the Khedivial Oprea House and that the city should be represented on that occasion by delegates of the Municipality and the corporations. There was a strong feeling that the memorial should be in Alexandria, but at the same time the meeting was in favour of working in accord with Cairo and the rest of Egypt. It was decided that a tubercolous institution was the most useful form which a memorial should take and that if such an instution should come into being, it was to be international and undenominational and that arrangements as to the food supply should be such as not in any way to impinge on Jewish or Moslem scruples in the same way as the Rudolph Home.

div.head: CAIRO COMMITTER
div.p: The committee provisionally formed to organise a public demonstration iu honour of Lord Cromer has decided that the ceremony shall take place on May 4th at 6 o'clock in the Opera House. A sub committee will prepare and issue invitations to as many as the theatre will hold. There will be two speeches in the name of the committee and Lord Cromer will reply. The committee has approved in principle the opening of a general subscription to be devoted to such a purpose as shall be eventually determined ; it has, moreover, recommended that the Municipality of Alexandria be invited with a view to the dignity of the occasion to cooperate with the Cairo committee by delegating such of their members as they may think best. Similar invitations will be issued to the other towns of Egypt, in order to allow all who are desirous of joining in the demonstration the opportunity to associate themselves with the measure finally adopted by the committee.

div.head:
KING OF SIAM
ARRIVAL AT SUEZ.
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT.)
Suez, Sunday.

The N.D.L. steamer Sachsen having on board H.R.H. the King of Siam arrived, at Suez last night, who was met by the Governor of Suez, Ibrahim Bay Halim, Youssei Pajha Zia, A. D C. to the Khedive, Said Bey Zoulfear, Master of Ceremonies, Shalch Bey, Commandant of tbs Suez Canal Police, and N. De Turris, Chief of Police. The Sachsen entered the Canal this morning at 4.30, and Youssef Pasha Zia, Said Bey Zoulficar, and Schalch Bey accompanied the king Ismailia, where arrangements have been made for his Roya Highness to land, and proceed by special Khedivial train to Port Said.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: "The Khedive," says "Al Akhbar,"intends to proceed to London immediately after his visit to Constantinople, where he will arrive in June. The same newspaper states that the Khedive will be the guest of King Edward.
Before coining to Alexandria the Khedive will visit Matarieh, which, our readers will remember, was burt down recently and where the inhabitants are homeless.

div.head: H. DE VRIES AND BOUTIGNY LTD.
div.p: We have received the prospectus of the issue of the H. de Vries and Boutigny Ltd. This new company with a capital of £st 300,000 has for object the taking over and extension of the business of the H. de Vries and Bouutigny firm which has for some years held a preponder ant position in the financial world of Egypt. The H. de Vries and Boutigny Ltd will undertake all banking transactions in Egypt and abroad. The capital of £300,000 is represented by 297,500 shares of £1 each and 50,000 founders' shares, 200,000 shares are offered for public subscription payable as follows :— 5/- on application, 5/- on allotment aud the rest by calls, following requirements, not to exceed 5/- and the internal between each call to be at least two months.

We would remind our readers that the administrative council is composed of M.M. Henri de Vries, Henri Boutigny, delegated administrators, and Count Max Lavison, at Cairo , Mr. Jacques Oppenheim of London ; Mr. W. C. Gibbons of the Gantes firm of Liverpool and Mr. L. Donnet of the Maison Le Grelles and Co. Bankers at Anvers, Brusells, at Paris.
We take from the prospectus the eminently favorable report of Messrs. Russell, Kerr, and Wyatt, the well-known accountant experts:—
H. DE VIRED & BOUTIGNY, LIMITED.

We have investigated the books and accounts of Messrs. H. de Vries et Boutigny, Cairo for the period from 1st of May, 1905, to 22nd March, 1907, and we certify that the Profits of the business for that period, before charging interest on Capital or Partners' salaries amount to £329,404 sterling.
Of these Profits, £195,780 sterling is derived from land transactions and £133,624 sterling from share transactions and other sources.
The Profits derived from land transaction include an amount of £88,577 sterling, payable at dates subsequent to the close of the financial period under review, and therefore, unrealized at this date.
(signed) RUSSELL, KERR & WYATT.

Few banking firms could justify such exceptional results and we might add that everything promises an equally satisfactory future. Let us remind our readers that the subscription will only be open on Wednesday next from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the offices of Messrs. H. de Vries and Boutigny, Sharia Kasr el Nil.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Omar Pasha Toussom left Alexandria this morning for the capital.
Lord Cromer will leave Port Said for England by the P. and O. steamship Egypt on May 6.
The Sirdar is expected to arrive at Cairo on Wednesday.
Saad Pasha Zaghloul, Minister of Education will leave for Europe in the latter part of June.

It has been decided to appoint Hussein Bey Rushdy, Councillor to the Native Court of Appeal, to the post of Director-General of Wakfs in place of Adly Pasha Yaghen, who will retire on pension. Rushdy Bey will receive the grade of mirmiran (pasha) shortly after his appointment.
Mr. Q. Vernazaa, the newly appointed representative of Bulgaria at Cairo, has left Sofia for Egypt.

div.head: COMPANY MEETING
div.p: THE RITZ HOTELS (EGYPT) LIMITED
The first ordinary or statutory meeting of the Ritz Hotels, (Egypt), Limited, was held at the offices of Messrs. Russell, Kerr and Wyatt, Cairo, on Friday the 12th inst at 4 p.m.

The required number of shareholders being present for the necessary quorum, the meeting was held. The number of shares represented was 40,262. The secretary read the notice convening the meeting and the auditors' certificate attached to the report of the directors. Mr. Charles Bacos was thereupon elected chairman of the meeting. On the motion of Mr. Matesdorf it was unanimously agreed to take the report as read, and on the motion of Mr. Matesdorf, and seconded by Mr. Bacos, a resolution was passed adopting the Report.
The two following contracts were then submitted for approval by the Meeting :-

One dated 22nd March, 1907, and made between the Ritz Hotels Development Co. Ltd. of the first part, the Ritz Hotels (Egypt) Ltd. of the second part, Charles Bacos of the third part and the Nile Land and Agricultural Co. of Alexandria of tho fourth part, and the other dated 22nd March, 1907, and made between the Ritz Hotels Development Co. Ltd., of the first part, the Ritz Hotels (Egypt) Ltd. of the second part, Ceasar Ritz of the third part, and Bacon Hans Pfyffer D'Altishofen of the fourth part.
The former of these contracts effects:-

(a) A modification of the contract, dated the 27th of Septemeber, 1906, and made between the Ritz Hotels and Development Co Lts. of the one part and Henry William Stickland on behalf of the company of the other part, as adopted by the agreement, dated the 12th day of December 1906, whereby the Company will become at liberty to extend or enlarge the hotel in course of erection by it, and to aquire or be interested in any new property without obtaining the consent of the development company, and without having to pay to the development company in respect of such consent a commision upon the shares or debentures to be paid in the future by the company for the purpose of such extension, enlargement or acquistion.

Clause 7 of such contract, so far as it relates to future prospectuses, and clauses Nos. 11, 12 and 13 therefore, and clause 9, expect so far as relates to the appointement of a Manager of the said Hotel, will be canceled

(b) a modification of the contract dated 27th September, 1906, and made between the development company of the 1st part, Charles Bacos of the 2nd part and the Nile Land and Agricultural Co. of the 3rd part, whereby Charles Bacos and the land company obtain liberty to be interested in other hotels in Egypt, and to use the namre of Ritz without consent of the development Co,. but not without the consent of the Ritz Hotels (Egypt) Limited and without being liable to pay a commission to the development as by the modified contract provided. The consideration for the said modifications is the payment by the company to the development company of the sume of twenty thousand pounds sterling.

By the latter of these contracts, which is part of the same arrangement, the company agrees to indemnify the development company against all claims by Mr. Ceaser Ritz under an agreement dated 20th November 1906, referred to in a prospectues of the Company and also in respect of an agreement made by the company with Barson Hand Pfyffer, dated the 6th December, 1906, under which these gentlemen would have become entitled to share in the future commission, and the benefits of such agreements are transferred to the company, Mr. Ritz and Baron Hans Pfyffer releasing all claim to the £20,000 above referred to.
On the motion Mr. Mosseri, seconded by Matire Carton de Wiart, it was resolved unanimously that tese contratcs be approved. Neither Baron Pfyffer, Mr. Matesdorf nor Mr. Bacos voted.
Mr. Matesdorf then addressed the meeting on behalf of the chairman as follows. :-

"As you are aware, the issue has been a great success , and the building of the hotel has been commenced and is going ahead with all speed compatible with good contraction Unfortunately contract prices for building material and operations had gone up considerably. We shall call you to an extrordinary meeting soon which will lutve several questions to consider.

"It is desirable to transferthe management to Egypt instead of having it in London, and the London board cannot under these circumstances continue the responsibility of control. This will necessitate a number of changes in the articles of association, which will to submitted for your approval. Then we are going to considerably enlarge the sphere to operations and do other hotel and property buisness at Cairo and Alexandria, and probably elsewhere. Again, we propose to abolish entirely the founders' shares and we will submit to you an arrangement which we consider equitable. All these proposals will require an increase of capital. We trust, subject to other arrangements, to obtain a sufficient guarantee of capital by the placing of shares at a suitable price. I hope that these projects will contribute to the success of our enterprise.''
Mr. Matesdorf on behalf of the chairman then thanked the shareholders for their attendance at the meeting. The proceedings were then terminated with a hearty vote of thanks to the chairman.
GESUCHT enine dentsche gepritfte Lehrerin zur Erteilung einiger Unterrichts studen taglich. Naheres bei der exped d. Blattes

Prospectuses and Application Forms can be obtained at the Bank of Athens 22, Fenchurch Street, London, E.C., and from Messrs. de VRIES and BOUTICNY'S, Stockbrokers and Bankers. Kasr-el-Nil Street, Cairo.
This Prospectus has been filed with the Registrar of Joint Stock Companies.

THE SUBSCRIPTION LIST will be opened in London at the Bank of Athene, and in Cairo at Messrs, H. de VRIES & BOUTIGNY'S on Wednesday, the 24th of April, 1907, at 9 a m., and close the same day at 4 p.m.
H. de Vries & Boutigny,
LIMITED
(Incorporated under The Companies Acts, 1862 to 1900.)
Capital, £stg. 300,000,
DIVIDED INTO

Of the founders' Shares 25,000 have been subscribed for by Messrs. HENRI H de VRIES and HENRI BOUTIGNY, and will be paid up in full by them, and the remaining 25,000 will be allotted to them or their nominees as fully paid.

The profits of the Company made during the financial year or other period comprised in the accounts submitted to the Ordinary General Meeting in each year with any profits carried forward from past years are applicable in order of priority and manner following :—

(1) 5% of such profits are to be carried to a reserve fund whilst and whenever such reserve fund amounts, to less than 10% of the paid-up capital, and 2 1/2% of such profits but not , exceeding £10,000 in any one year is to be paid to each of the first Managing Directors whilst holding such office as additional remuneration for his services.
(2) The balance is applicable to the payment of a cumulative preferential dividend to the close of such period at the rate of 5% per annum on the Capital paid up on the Ordinary Shares.

(3) Of the surplus 5%, but not exceeding £15,000 in any one year, is to be paid to the Directors as additional remuneration for their services, 50% is applicable to the payment of a further dividend on the capital up on the Ordinary Shares or may be carried to reserve or otherwise dealt with as the Company in General Meeting determine and 45 % is to be divided rateably among the holders of the Founders' Shares.

In case of a winding up any surplus assets after repayment of capital are to be divided as to 50 .% amongst the holders of the Ordinary Shares in proportion to tho number held, and to the remaining 50 % amongst the holders of the Founders' Shares in proportion to the number held.
200,000 Ordinary Shares are now offered for Public Subscription
PAYABLE AS FOLLOWS
5s. per Share on Application,
5s. per Share on Allotment,

and the balance in Calls as and when required, not exceeding 5s. each at intervals of not less than Two months. Shares warrants to Bearer will be issued in respect of fully paid shares upon payment of the stamp duties.

div.head: PROSPECTUS
div.p: The Company has been formed to acquire and take over as a going concern and to develop and extend the well-known business of Stockbrokers, Bankers and Estate Agents, carried on at Cairo by the firm of H. de Vries and Boutigny and for the other purposes mentioned in its Memorandum of Association.

The Business was established in the year 1905 by the present partners, Messrs Henri Heiman de Vries and Boutigny, and has been remarkably successful. Its great development has so increased the magnitude of the undertaking, that Messrs. deVries and Boutigny consider that the time has arrived for converting the business into a public Company.
Messrs, de Vries and Boutigny have agreed to act as Managing Directors of the Company for a period of five years.

In addition the Company will acquire the lease of the offices in Kasr-el Nil Street, held for a term expiring on the 10th of March, 1908, and of the offices in Soliman Pacha Street, the term of which expires on the 28th February, 1909, as well Ks the furniture and effects therein.
The books of the business have recently been investigated by Messrs. Russell, Kerr and Wyatt, Chartered Accountants, who have given the following certificate:
Cairo, 5th April, 1907.
To the Directors of
H. de VRIES BOUTIGNY, LIMITED.

We have investigated the books and accounts of Messrs. H. de Vries & Boutigny, Cairo for the period from 1st of May, 1905, to 22nd March, 1907, and we certify that the Profits of the business for that period, before charging interest on Capital or Partners' Salaries amount to £329,404 sterling.
Of these Profits, £195,780 sterling is derived from land transactions, and £133,624 sterling from share transactions and other sources.
The Profits derived from land transactions include an amount of £88,577 sterling, payable at dates subsequent to the close of the financial period under review, and therefore unrealized at this date.
RUSSELL, KERR & WYATT.

The Vendors who are the said firm and its partners will pay all their debts and liabilities in connection with the business as at the 30th April, 1907, and the buisness will be taken over by the Company with all pending contracts and engagements as from that day, and the Company will have the benefit of all profits realized from that date, but will repay to the Vendors all moneys expended by them in connection with pending contracts and engagements taken over upon the completion of the same provided they result in a profit.
The purchase price has been fixed by tho Vendors, who are the promoters of the Company, at £150,000, of which £148,000 is for the goodwill.

The purchase price will be paid and satisfied as to £51,250 in cash, and as to £98,750 in fully-paid Shares of the Company, which will be paid and allotted as follows :— To Mr. Henri H. de Vries £25,625 in cash and 48,750 Ordinary Shares, and to Mr. Henry Boutigny £26,625 in cash, and 48,750 Ordinary Shares, and to both of them jointly 25,000 Founders' Shares, they being interested in equal shares in the business and in the property to be acquired by the Company.

The Vendors have agreed to pay all preliminary expenses of forming and floating the Company down to and including the first general allotment of Ordinary Shares to the public, i estimated at £stg.2,000, and have by the Memorandum of Association guaranteed the subscription of the balance of 200,000 of Ordinary Shares, and they haye subscribed the Memorandum of Association for 25,000 of the Founders' Shares ; they are interested in these liabilities and in the Founders' Shares subscribed by them and generally in the promotion of the Company in equal shares.
The minimum subscription on, which the Directors may proceed to allotment is 25 percent of the Shares offered.
The following Contracts have been entered into :—

A Contract dated the 28th March botween the Vendors, the firm of H. de Vries and Boutigny, and Henri Herman de Vries, and Henri Boutigny, all of Cairo the one part, and the Company of the other part, being the Contract for sale, and a Contract dated the 28th March, 1907, between the Company of the one part, and the said Henri Herman de Vries and Henri Boutigny of the other part, being a Contract for the employment of Messsrs de Vries and Boutigny as Managing Directors.
This Contract contains the following provisions

list.item: The said Henri Herman de Vries and Henri Boutigny (hereinafter called the first Managing Directors) shall respectively by entitled to hold office as Managing Directors) of the Company for a term of five years from the time when the Company shall become entitled to commence business, and in the event of one of them, vacating office by death, resignation or otherwise, the otfier shall be the sole Managing Director for the remainder of the said term.

The first Managing Directors whilst holding such office, and after one of them vacates such office, the other whilst holding office shall have full control of the business of the Company, and subject to any direction to the contrary of the Board of Directors shall have all the powers of the Directors under these presents.

So long as the first Managing Directors or either of them snail hold such office, no other Director or Directors of the Company shall be appointed without the consent of such first Managing Directors or Director.

The first Managing Directors or Director whilst holding such office shall well and faithfully serve the Company and use their best endeavours to promote the interest thereof, and they shall each be entitled to four consecutive calendar months' leave of absence in every year at times convenient to them.

Each of the first Managing Directors whilst holding such office shall hold his Membership of the Cairo Bourse for the benefit of the Company, and shall use his best endeavours to continue such Membership, and shall not operate on the said Bourse except on behalf of the Company.

In addition to their remuneration as Directors, each of the first Managing Directors whilst holding such office shall be paid as remuneration for their services a fixed salary at the rate of £ stg 3,000 per annum, and each of them whilst holding such office shall be paid the share of profits mentioned in sub-clause 1 of article 118 of the Company's Articles of Association (the effect of which is set out on page 1 of this Prospectus).

div.p: The following are extracts from the Company's Articles of Association : —

86. The qualification of a Director shall be the holding of Ordinary shares of the Company to the nominal value of £10. A first Director may act before acquiring his qualification, but shall in any case acquire the same within one month from his appointment, and unless he shall do so he shall be deemed to have agreed to take the said shares from the Company and the same shall be forthwith allotted to him accordingly.

87. As remuneration for their services eafch Director shall be paid a fixed salary at the rate of £200 per annum, and such further sums as the Company in General Meeting may from time to time determine. And tho Directors shall also be paid' collectively the share of surplus profits hereinafter mentioned, and such remuneration shall be divided among them in such proportions and manner as they may determine, and in default of such determination equally.

98. The Directors for the time being may from time to time appoint one or more of their body to be a Managing Director or Managing Directors of the Company, and on such terms and conditions as they think fit. The said Henri Herman de Vries and Henri Boutigny shall be the Managing Directors of the Company, and are hereinafter referred to as the first Managing Directors.

101. The remuneration of a Managing Director sliall from time to time be fixed by the Directors, and may be by way of salary or commission, or participation in profits, or by any or all of those modes. A Managing Director shall, unless otherwise determined, be entitled to remuneration as a Director.

110. If any of the Directors shall be called upon to perform extra services for any of the purposes of tho Company, the Company shall remunerate the Director or Directors of such manner as may be determined by the Directors.

115. The Directors may from time to time provide for the management of the affairs of the Company in any special locality in any part of the world in such manner as they shall think fit, and the provisions contained in the six next following clauses shall be without prejudice to the general powers conferred by this paragraph :-

(1) The directors from time to time and at any time may establish any local boards or agencies for advising the Directors as to the conduct of the Company's business or for managing any of the affairs of the Company in any specified locality in any part of the world, and may appoint any persons to be members of such local board, or any managers or agents, and may fix their remuneration.

Copies of the Memorandum and Articles of Association, and of the above-mentioned Contract and Accountants' Certificate, can be inspected at the Bank of Athens, 22, Fenchurch Street, London, E.C., Messrs, de Vries and Boutigny's, Cairo, at any time during business hours.
A copy of the Company's Memorandum of Association is printed in the fold of this Prospectus and forms part of it.

Applications for Shares should bo made upon the form accompanying the Prospectus, and sent to the Bank of Athens, 22, Fenchurch Street London, E. C., or Messrs, de Vries and Boutigny, Kasr-el-Nil Street, Cairo, together with the amount of the deposit.

Where no allotment is made the deposit will be returned in full, and where the number of Shares allotted is less than the number applied for, the Balance of the deposit will be applied towards the remaining payments.
Failure to pay any instalments-on Shares allotted when due will render previous payments liable to forfeiture.
Dated 15th April, 1907.

TO LET. House-Boat, after May 10th : partly furnished, Rooms :— two bed, two sitting, bath, servants' kitchen. House, Rod- el-Farag, open country. near tram. Three bedrooms, one sitting; kitchen etc : Full particulars from Rev : R. MacInnee, 2, Sharia- el-Manakh, Cairo.

div.head:
THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
QUESTION OF DISARMAMENT.
GERMAN OBJECTION TO DISCUSSION.

div.p: The chief of the Liberal-Radicals, Herr Mullet Sagan, member of the Interparliamentary Union for Arbitration, publishes an article directed against the discussion of the question of disarmament at the Hague Conference. This article may be looked upon as indicating that entire public opinion in Germany, even in the Radical middle class circles, does not desire a discussion of the question of disarmament at the Hague Conference. (Reuter)

div.head:
FRANCE AND MOROCCO.
SULTAN CONCEDES DEMANDS.

div.p: The "Standard" learns that the Sultan of Morocco has agreed to all the French demands.
(Renter)

div.head:
SPANISH LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS
RIOTS AT BARCELONA.

div.p: The legislative elections here have passed quietly. At Barcelona there were riots. One person was killed and two wounded.
(Havcas)

div.head:
THE MAUCHAMP MURDER
EXECUTION OF ASSASSINS.

div.p: The French Consul at Mazagan has left for Marakesh to attend the execution of Dr. Mauchamp's murderers.
(Havas)
The Albanians of the Koumons, Precheoo, and Ghilane districts are opposing the reforms and are endeavouring to force the Servians to join them, whereas the latter are in favour of the reforms.
(Havas)

div.head:
PEPPER COAST ROBBERS.
REFUGE CAPTURED BY FRENCH.

div.p: The French have taken Boussedon (Upper Guinea), the refuge of the Liberian robbers, who have suffered heavy losses. A French lieutenant and a sharp-shooter were killed and ten wounded.
(Havas)

div.head:
INVITATIONS FROM GERMANY.
MAYORAL AND EDITORIAL VISITS.

div.p: The Burgomaster of Berlin has invited the Lord Mayos and Sheriffs to visit Berlin at the end of May. German editors have also invited British editors to visit the German capital and other parts of the country.
(Reuter)

div.head:
SUEZ CANAL REGULATION.
BENZINE AND PATROL PROHIBITION.

div.p: The Suez Canal Committee has decided to abolish the regulation prohibiting the passage through the Canal of tank steamers carrying benzine or petrol in bulk. It is uncertain when the abolition will take effect, but it is expected in a few days at the latest.
(Reuter)

div.head:
DESTROYER SUNK AT MALTA.
COLLISION WITH BREAKWATER.

div.p: The destroyer Ariel, whilst manoeuvring during a night attack outside the harbour, collided with the breakwater and sank. It is feared that she is a total wreck. The coxswain has been drowned.
(Reuter)

div.head:
ANOTHER STRONG EARTHQUAKE
VOLCANIC LAKE ERUPTS.

div.p: A volcanic lake at Nahuelhoapi is fiercely in eruption accompanied by a strong earthquake : people are fleeing : many cattle have been killed : the deposit of ashes reaches a distance of 150 miles.

A steamer, with 60 passengers on board, while crossing the Neva yesterday evening collided with a large icefloe, overturned, and quickly sank. In the panic few secured life belts. Two other steamers picked up 15 people. None reached the bank, the swift current carrying them under the icefloes. (Renter)
A steamboat has foundered ; fifty people were drowned. (Havas)
The police have discovered another large consignment of ammunition for Russian revolutionaries in a blacksmith's shop in Edinburgh.
(Reuter)
Pessimistic rumours are current concerning the fate of the Duma. (Havas)
The rumours of the dissolution of the Duma is denied in official circles. (Havas)
The Minister of the Interior has withdrawn his resignation. (Reuter)
The business section of Iloilo has been saved.
(Reuter)
The cruiser Rome has been launched in the presenco of the King.
The bakers have resumed work. (Havas)

div.head:
HOME FOOTBALL.
CUP WON BY SHEFFIELD.

div.p: Cup Final. Sheffield on Wednesday defeated Everton by 2 to 1. (Reuter)

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY
div.p: FLOWER SHOW AT SAN STEFANO.

The twelfth annual exhibition of the Alexandria Horticultural Society was held at San Stetano on Saturday.' and Sunday. The Khedive, who had arrived from Cairo on Friday evening to attend the performance at the Zizinia Theatre for the Orwa el Woska Society opened show. His Highness arrived at San Stefano at the four o'clock accompanied by the Grand Master of Ceremonies and Lewa Watson Pasha and was received by Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel and the committee of the Society, after which he went round the exhibition, showing great interest in the many exhibits.

In consequence of the easino being rebuilt the usual rooms were not available and therefore the whole of the large terrace by the sea was tented in and the groups arranged in the form of a garden. The effect was certainly striking and the large groups of annuals competing for the handsome objet d'art offered by Baron Felix Menasce gave brightness to the scene. There was good competition in this class and the winner was Ahmed Yehia Pasha whose plants were well arranged and showed on the whole better cultivation than the others. The second important feature of the show was the mass of magnificent gladioli which were competing for the large silver vase offered by Prince Hussein Kamel. As every competitor had to produce fifty stems and these were arranged on rows of tables, the effect was very striking. Prince Omar Toussoun who gained the prize certainly staged the finest exhibit of gladiolus that has ever been seen in Egypt, but the competition was close enough among the seven competitors to make the judges' task a difficult one. Prince Omar Toussoun staged a very large collection of palms on the new balcony of the terrace and close by were three large azaleas, which came from the greenhouses of Mr. Salvago. Mr. Tramontina arranged a large group in front of the entrance which made quite a fine collection of cyclamen, which must be rather rare so late in the year. It was interesting to see that the exhibitors who won the £30 objet d'art last year for fancy pelargoniums were able to produce quite as good specimens again this year, showing that good attention must have been paid to their plants and that they had been able to keep them through the hot summer.

The table decorations were arranged in the hotel diningroom, which was just large enongh for the seven exhibits and for the vases arranged by amateurs. Miss Hewat took the first prize with her table very effectively decorated with single white roses arched from a high vase in the centre to the four corners of the table-centre, and small vases of the same flower were prettily arranged on the table, while each finger-bowl contained one blossom. The second prize was accorded to Miss G. Atkin, whose table, which was close to the door, was decorated with white flag iris and petuniasin vases and iris spread over the table. The third table, decorated by Miss Allen, was carried out in spirea. Miss Allen arranged a very artistic vase of hibiscus and Miss Hewat's simple vase of swan river daisies was quite charming. There were many tables of cut flowers, including roses, pelargoniums, and annuals, but the light was bad and we should recommend the committee to see next year if some arrangement could not be made by which the tenting could be abandoned and the terrace closed in with glass.

The vegetables occupied a large tent by the sea. With the exception of the fine exhibit of Bartau Bey, for which a special prize was given, there were few amateur exhibits, the only collection worthy of mention being a good general exhibit by Mr. F. Haselden which was "hors concours." With regard to the natives it is quite certain that there has been great improvement not only as far as attendance is concerned but also in the quality of vegetable exhibited.

The Municipality, who had a special test reserved for them last year, showed their plants in a large corner of the terrace. There is or doubt that every year the Municipality shows better plants and a better arrangement and although this exhbit was not for competition yet the judges recommended that a silver gilt medal should be offered to Mr. Monfront, chiei of the parks together with the thanks of the committee to the Municipality.

Mr. Fish, the new Secretary of the society showed himself most indefatigable throughout the exhibition and the preliminary work, and we can congratulate the Society having secured the services of one so capable and wh shows such great intrest in the work.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Wakfs Khédiviau Privés met de nouveau aux enchères publique 133 feddans, 4 kirats et 20 sahmes, réparti comme suit:

row.cell: Nahiet el Beida, Moudirieh de Béhéra (1)

div.p: N.B.—(l) Une parcelle sise dans ce village près de la gare d'Ezbet-Khouchid est limitée: au Sid, par le chemin qui va du petit quai jusqu'à El Mahmoudieh. au Nord par d'autres terrains du Wakf. a l'Est, par la digue du canal el Mahmoudieh. A l'Ouest, par le digue du chemin de fer. Un plan de cette parcelle se trouve à l'Administration. La mise à prix de chaque feddan es de 1000 L.E.
(2) La mise à prix de chaque feddan de ces parcelles est de 150 L.E.
Dans la séance du 15 Novembre 1905 date anterieurement fixés pour la premiere adjudication, les offres n'ayant pas été favorables, la vent a été adjournée.
L'Administation tiendra le jeudi 25 Avril 1907 une séance à son siege au Palais d'Abdine.

Les personnes qui désirent prendre part à vente peuvent, après la visite des lieux et après avoir pris connaissance des conditions d'echange, présenter leurs offres sous pli cacheté l'adresse de S.E. le Directeur de l'Administation.
Les offres ne devront pas etre inferieures au prix nominal indiqué ci-dessus et seront accompagneées d'un cautionnement qui ne pourr être inferieure 10 % de la valeur.
L'Administration se reserve le driot d'acccepter ou de refuser toute offre qui lui sera adressée sans aucune responsabilité de sa part.
